node.text:
Because of its significant environmental impacts, advancing the carbon footprint of the construction industry is an important part of finding future-proof solutions.

In the project Biocrete, Snøhetta teamed up with some of Norway’s most experienced contractors, researchers, producers and suppliers within the concrete and biochar industry, aiming to develop a net carbon negative concrete. By pyrolyzing scraps, cut offs and waste wood from the construction industry, biochar is made. When mixed in with the cement, the CO2 is sequestered at such a scale that the CO2 emissions from the concrete production are compensated for by the carbon in the biochar. The collaboration resulted in the first net carbon-negative precast concrete wall being cast on March 16 in Orkanger, Norway.

By both combating a growing waste problem and the world’s increasing CO2 emissions, this solution has the potential to significantly decrease the environmental footprint of this widely used material and contribute to making concrete a much-needed planet-positive contribution for specific applications.

node.text:
As the most widely used building material in the world, concrete plays a significant role in the carbon footprint of the building and construction industry. Its key component, cement, is the source of about 8 % of the world's CO2 emissions, according to think tank Chatham House. 

The chemical and thermal combustion processes involved in the production of cement places the material with CO2 emissions above aviation fuel (2.5 %) and not far behind agriculture (12 %). To reach the goals of the Paris Agreement, annual global CO2 emissions linked to concrete will need to fall by steeply in the next few years. 

As a response to this, Snøhetta has entered a strategic partnership with Norwegian startup Saferock to pilot and market the production of a more sustainable concrete. 

By utilizing industrial by-products to make geopolymer concrete, Snøhetta and Saferock estimates that carbon emissions associated with the production of concrete can be reduced by more than 70 % as a first step. By 2025, the aim is to produce fully CO2 neutral concrete.

More info at snohetta.com and saferock.no

Video by @bjornar_ovrebo and @kjetilandersen

node.title: Geopolymer concrete – the construction material of the future?

node.text:
Here’s a little video showcasing more of our design for the new ASI Reisen headquarters in Natters, Austria. By offering solutions that will enable the long-term low environmental footprint of the office space, this flexible and open office space over several floors constitutes a healthy and enjoyable working environment for its users. The building is tailor-made for the needs of ASI Reisen and reflects the values of the company in an intuitive and generous way.

Video by Stefan Krösbacher

node.text: Have a look at the new mini documentary about Snøhetta, created in collaboration with @visitnorway. In the film, we are discussing how architecture interacts with nature, our philosophy, and what role the Norwegian nature has played for some of our most renowned projects. The full video can be watched on our IGTV-channel, or via the link in our bio. #visitnorway #osloopera #peergynt 📷 @willynikkers

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Snøhetta on September 09, 2021. May be an image of indoor.

node.text: As the world continues to absorb the reverberations of the events of September 11, 2001, we at Snøhetta take this moment to pause and reflect. Beginning in 2004, Snøhetta had the privilege of working on the National September 11th Memorial Museum Pavilion, a structure designed to support and guide visitors at the Memorial grounds. Created as the only new building on the memorial plaza, the Museum Pavilion is designed to broaden one’s experience. The transformative spaces act as a threshold between the bustle of Lower Manhattan and the contemplative spaces of the museum and memorial. The reflective façade of the Pavilion allows visitors to see themselves in the context of those around them, reminding us that while we exist as individuals, we do so collectively and with each other.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Snøhetta on September 06, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and indoor.

node.text:
The coexistence of digital and analog work processes has been at Snøhetta’s core since the very beginning. The collaboration between our Adelaide Studio and the Oslo-based product design team in the creation of the Intersection Worktable is a manifestation of this process: From the initial brief and ideation, through sketching, detailing and design, the worktable was made by hand in the Adelaide workshop space. 

The hands-on craft capabilities, enabled through our workshops, allow us to investigate and explore materials like the wood, plastic, concrete and glass, to be used both for commissioned projects and internal research.

node.text:
The Intersection Worktable is made from environmentally friendly reclaimed Tasmanian Oak, sourced from Tasmania, at one of the world’s first underwater forestry operations. Unlike any other type of timber, the wood is ethically sourced and reclaimed from an ancient forest lost under water for 25 years. The unique wood is identified by its pronounced pattern and imperfections that can’t be found in typically sourced oak. The wood gives the table warm, illustrious qualities, breaking with the traditional office furniture materials. The smooth surfaces express the texture of the naturally preserved wood with its unique gradients of color reflecting its history.

Photos by Grant Hancock and @hydrowood

node.text:
With materials sourced from the depths of Lake Pieman in Tasmania, and inspired by its home in a Bondi Beach office space, the Intersection Worktable merges a conventional worktable with material exploration and sculptural furniture. 

Reaching almost five meters long, the bespoke worktable is an eye-catching centerpiece in the space. Starting from the concept of Intersection, we investigated the potential and limitations materials unique to the Australian continent, juxtaposing textures, and intersecting planes. 

The tabletop design is one continuous form, like the flow of water, inspired by the endless Australian coastline. Where the edges meet, there is a juxtaposition of textures and gradients in the material. Smoothly angled corners are a subtle imitation of forms developed in nature. This unbroken, rounded language is further picked up in the rounded legs.

See snohetta.com for more! 

Photos by Grant Hancock

Photo by Snøhetta in Innsbruck, Austria. May be an image of child and outdoors.

node.text:
The Norwegian National Opera and Ballet in Oslo offer people not only the possibility to go to the opera, but also to walk on it. We’re always looking for the on, under, next to and in-between as continuations of a space offering new relations of body and space. 

The exhibition “The body and the space” at the Tyrolean Architecture Center in Innsbruck (@aut.architektur.tirol), explores this relationship of the body and the real, social and virtual space. The spatial experience on the roof of the opera is one of 114 contributions on this sensual cognizance – whether as an individual or as a group. 

The exhibition will run until September 18, so make sure you stop by before then!

Photo by Patrick Lüth

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Snøhetta on August 30, 2021.

node.text:
Our exhibition, Arctic Nordic Alpine – In Dialogue with Landscape, is on display until October 13 at @galeriejaroslavafragnera in Prague. Featuring contemporary architecture in vulnerable landscapes, it investigates the impact these new constructions have on these extreme geographic, climatic environments. 

With the passion to create, our imagination let us involve the stories told by nature, translating these stories into architectural form and language. Conceived and designed by Snøhetta, the exhibition is a work in itself and is designed to travel. It can now be experienced in Prague.

Photos by Michal Barbuscak

node.text:
The ability to merge landscape and architecture is extremely important when developing visions for a sustainable urban future. For our approach to this, Snøhetta received the LILA Honour Award 2021 earlier this year.

Our master plan for the 135-hectare Budapest South Gate site is based on innovative approaches to sustainable urban development. 

Recreational spaces and public squares as well as retention and drainage areas define a blue-green infrastructure for processing rain and surface water, and feeding the natural water circulation. In addition, these open and green spaces ensure a comfortable microclimate, prevent heat islands from forming, and increase biodiversity in the city. The integration of natural dynamics within the built structures and the consistent urban design vision creates a distinct identity for this new vibrant urban quarter in direct relation to the river.
 
📷 @zoa3d

node.text: We are currently recruiting landscape architecture talent to join our New York and San Francisco studios. We're looking for Project Landscape Architects who have previous experience leading an internal team, coordinating with consultants, and who have experience with all phases of design and construction. We're also looking for a Senior Project Landscape Architect in San Francisco. Find out more on our Careers Page online!

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Snøhetta in Lascaux. May be an image of 2 people and outdoors.

node.text:
Situated at the intersection of a densely forested hillside and the agricultural Vézère Valley, the Lascaux IV Caves Museum was conceived as a fine cut in the landscape, inviting visitors into a curious world of prehistory. Five years after the opening, we’re excited to see that it’s also a playground for local skateboarders such as @_gregcln!

“The architecture of Lascaux IV is a real playground for skateboarding. It combines parietal art, architecture and street sports. I’m from Montignac and I enjoy practice skateboarding here.”

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Snøhetta on August 17, 2021. May be an image of indoor.

node.text:
The additional exhibition spaces at @ordrupgaard dedicated to the museum’s impressionistic art are made up of two smaller and one larger space in a light color and material palette. The spaces are designed in close collaboration with the museum and are all furnished with oak floors, walls, and ceilings, providing a light, organic and warm atmosphere. Gypsum boards are mounted on the walls allowing for the museum to effortlessly curate art pieces and change the color palette of each exhibition room when needed. The exhibition ceilings are covered with oak veneer cassettes with carefully integrated light installations, providing a seamless and harmonious design that places the art pieces at the center of attention.

Contrasting with the reflective steel exterior that is partially visible from the outside, the inside of the exhibition spaces creates a sense of softness and comfort, echoing almost the design of a classic vintage jewelry box, with its hard, metallic exterior and soft, velvety lining on the inside.

📷 @laura_stamer

node.text:
Originally built as a three-winged country mansion in the neo-classical style during World War I, @ordrupgaard was expanded by a modern 1,150 m2 glass and black lava concrete extension in 2005, designed by @zahahadidarchitects. Snøhetta’s design, most of which is underground, but also partly excavated from the landscape, creates a holistic and continuous path throughout the entire museum and its surrounding park and gardens, linking Hadid’s extension for special exhibitions with the museum’s original building and permanent collection. 

The largest of the three main exhibition spaces designed by Snøhetta can be partly seen from the outside as a monolithic, steel-coated sculpturesque structure that seems somewhat excavated from a larger volume below ground. Just like a hidden treasure that reveals itself as it appears during excavation, the structure glistens in the landscape. Cut in a wide range of different facets and polished in different directions, the structure creates a play of light throughout the days and shifting seasons. 

📷 @laura_stamer

node.text:
Today marks the opening of our new extension and landscape for @ordrupgaard in Denmark. Situated in Charlottenlund, north of Copenhagen, Ordrupgaard houses Northern Europe’s most comprehensive collection of French and Danish art from the 19th and early 20th century. 

Conceptually dubbed “Himmelhaven” (“Heaven’s Garden”) the extension exterior is very much a “clin d’œil” to the impressionistic art period, characterized by its constant efforts to capture light and its changing qualities, and immortalized on canvases by world-renowned artists such as Manet, Monet, Degas, and Renoir.

Referred to by the architects as a “third parterre”, Snøhetta’s extension marks a continuation of the landscape and is placed at the intersection of Ordrupgaard’s English style park with its deciduous trees, many of them fruit bearing, and an adjacent smaller French-inspired rose garden.

See snohetta.com for more! 

📷 @laura_stamer
